Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Understanding the Earth's Crust during the Presence of Large Amounts of Pre-eruptive Magma Conditions at Volcanic Zones
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to understand the Earth's crust at a time when large amounts of magma evolved and became primed for eruption. This project will amalgamate fieldwork, lab work, and computer simulations to study the evolution of the magma bodies that fed the Whakamaru eruptions. The Whakamaru group erupted intensely and explosively; they evacuated hundreds of cubic kilometers of magma in short episodes in the Taupo Volcanic Zone, New Zealand. Large eruptions, like the Whakamaru, provide snapshots of the Earth's crust at times when large amounts of magma are present, and their study yields insights into the ability of the crust to generate eruptible magma. Understanding the development and conditions of pre-eruptive magma bodies is paramount to assess hazards and comprehend the magnitude of potential eruptions. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Darren Gravley at University of Canterbury, New Zealand whose expertise in volcanology and knowledge of the Whakamaru deposits will be instrumental for the work to be developed.

The project focuses on quantifying how magma was distributed in the subsurface leading to the Whakamaru eruption sequence. Using erupted natural pumice samples, we can quantify the pre-eruptive magma conditions using crystal-glass thermodynamic equilibrium. Results will make it possible to distinguish particular batches of magma stored at different crustal depths, and also provide insight on the organization and potential interactions between discrete magma bodies. The project also focuses on quantifying the heat flow between the magma body and crust associated with the Whakamaru Group. Phase equilibria modeling will quantify the heat needed within the upper crust to generate and store such quantities of magma, and will assess the conditions of the crust during magma storage. Both conductive and convective heat flow within the crust will be modeled based on the constraints placed by the thermodynamics of crystallizing magma.

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Royal Society of New Zealand.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research is to determine what crustal and magmatic conditions allow for the development of a supereruption. We focus on the Whakamaru eruptions in the Taupo Volcanic Zone (TVZ), New Zealand. The TVZ is an exemplary location to study how supereruptions develop, as it is the most active silicic volcanic region in the world and provides recent, easily accessible volcanic deposits. The Whakamaru eruptions were erupted at ~340 ka and are the largest eruptions in TVZ history. They erupted at a particularly interesting time in TVZ history, as there was relative quiessence before the eruptions, and an increase in large eruptions after the Whakamaru eruptions. 

Understanding the development and conditions of pre-eruptive magma bodies is paramount to assess hazards and comprehend the magnitude of potential eruptions. We discover information about past volcanic events to inform how we handle the threat of future eruptions and the hazards associated with living near an active volcanic landscape.

Eruption of the Whakamaru units transformed the organization of the upper crust and led to a change in the nature of the magmas that erupted afterwards. The overarching goal for this project is to bring the snapshot of the crust into focus at a time when the Whakamaru magmas evolved and became primed for eruption. 

We confirm that there are multiple magma bodies that fed the Whakamaru eruptions. They can be distinguished based on their geochemical composition and their mineralogy. There are two main types of magma erupted, and both types erupted throughout the Whakamaru eruptions.

The distinct magma bodies were stored at very similar crustal levels of ~100-150 MPa, which shows that the crust must accommodate large amounts of magma over a fairly shallow pressure range. 

Several undergraduate students were involved in this research. They were involved in fieldwork, sample preparation, and analysis. Connections with the University of Canterbury were strengethed, highlighting the benefit of international collaborations.
